thread.title: Forest de Lockwood's collection largely unloved at auction
thread.title_full: Forest de Lockwood's collection largely unloved at auction | afr.com

author: Jane O'Sullivan
title: Forest de Lockwood's collection largely unloved at auction
text:
An Egyptian bronze cat, circa 664-332 BC, which sold as part of the Forest de Lockwood collection. by Jane O'Sullivan The collection of Forest de Lockwood, a key designer of the Aesthetic movement of the 19th century, failed to spark much interest at the Bonhams sale in Sydney on Tuesday.
The collection, consigned by his Australia-based grandson, included two rare pieces of furniture designed by de Lockwood.
The vitrine sold for $7,320 on an estimate of $6,000 to $9,000, while the elm chest failed to meet its $4,000 to $6,000 estimate. Sale prices include a buyer's premium of 22 per cent while estimates do not.
There was some interest in the curios de Lockwood collected during his travels – an 18th century Indian illustration of Shaykh Ibrahim with angels made $7,930 on an estimate of $800 to $1,200 and an ancient Egyptian bronze cat made $6,710 on an estimate of $5,500 to $7,000 – but his paintings stalled.
Only one of the 21 in the collection sold, and it made $3,660 at the lower end of its estimate.
The paintings comprised around a third of the auction, and without these sales and without strong results for the furniture pieces, the collection brought in just $55,300.
